verses.text: O LORD, how many are my foes! How many rise up against me!
Many are saying of me, "God will not deliver him." Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 3 Surrounded by trouble and crying out to the Lord in distress, the psalmist expresses deep trust in God. The psalm was originally composed when David fled from Absalom and battled against revolt. The military terminology throughout the psalm may indicate that it continued to be used in warfare.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 Many . . . rising. The number and nature of the foes betrays the royal origin of the psalm. The foes of the nation are also the king’s foes.

verses.text: But you are a shield around me, O LORD; you bestow glory on me and lift up my head.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3:3
rsbNotes.text: 3:3 lifter of my head. An expression of encouragement.

verses.text: To the LORD I cry aloud, and he answers me from his holy hill. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3:4
rsbNotes.text: 3:4 holy hill. That is, Zion (see note Ps. 2:6). God designated Zion as the place where His people could approach Him through sacrifice.

verses.text: I lie down and sleep; I wake again, because the LORD sustains me.
I will not fear the tens of thousands drawn up against me on every side.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 I lay down and slept. As in Ps. 91, the psalmist is able to sleep in the war camp, though the enemy surrounds him.

verses.text: Arise, O LORD! Deliver me, O my God! Strike all my enemies on the jaw; break the teeth of the wicked.
From the LORD comes deliverance. May your blessing be on your people. Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 3:7
rsbNotes.text: 3:7 Arise. This expression is typical of psalms sung at the beginning of war. God fights for His people against their flesh and blood enemies.
